div.p: There are two things put me upon this Preface: Fir≈øt, Geo. Whitehead and his Abettors's Inveterate Malice, calling me and others Old canker'd Apo≈øtates, Vile Apo≈øtates, Self-condemn'd Apo≈øtates, Unruly Bea≈øts, Betraying Juda≈ø≈øes, Wolves, Dogs, Enemies of all Righteou≈øne≈øs, Children of the Devil, Devils Incarnate, Heathens, Athei≈øts, &c. Indeed their Books are ≈øo very Malicious and Defamatory, as well as their private Whi≈øperings and Backbitings, that ≈øome even of them≈øelves have been con≈øtrained to give me under their Hands a Te≈øtimony in Writing again≈øt the unchri≈øtian Treatment which I have met withal; namely, T. Bird, J. Ellington, J. Ma≈øon, W. Bel≈øham, and above Twenty more Quakers belonging to Mildenhall-Meeting: And yet not wor≈øe Language than they have given the Publick Mini≈øtry; as Witches, Devils, Gormandizing Prie≈øts, &c. as anon will appear. And whoever di≈øcovers their Errors, and di≈øplays them in their proper Colours, mu≈øt expect to meet with ≈øomething of this kind: And that being fore-≈øeen, have doubtle≈øs been taken for a tolerable Excu≈øe by abler Pens from ≈øtooping to ≈øuch an Undertaking as this: And thereupon I may the more rationally expect the more favourable Cen≈øure for what might have been done better by the Learned; 'tis enough to me to be thought worthy in this great Work (of di≈øcovering the greate≈øt Here≈øie that ever ≈øprang up in our Age) to be as the Carpenter's Man, who≈øe Work is to hew off the rough and knotty pieces of the Timber, to make it more ready for better Workmen.

To be Contentious I grant is an Offence the Scriptures condemn with no little keenne≈øs, whil≈øt it exhorts to contend earne≈øtly for the Faith once delivered to the Saints. From whence I conceive, that though I contend again≈øt Quakeri≈øm with ≈øome Symptoms of Zeal, I am not therefore Contentious; nor though I may retract, yea, write again≈øt ≈øome Errors I formerly held, and upon Conviction have for≈øaken: I am not therefore a Self-condemned Apo≈øtate, as G. W. dreams. If you think me too ≈ømart in ≈øome pa≈ø≈øages again≈øt Per≈øons, 'tis again≈øt their Leaders; if again≈øt their Opinions, I have from their own Books proved them Erroneous and Bla≈øphemous, which ought to be reproved ≈øharply: And that their Opinions are ≈øo, I have never refu≈øed to make Proof of to their faces, on Condition when proved they would engage a Retractation; nay, ≈øometimes without any ≈øuch Engagement. See Quakeri≈øm Anatomized, p. 2. I cannot call Gall and Poy≈øon by ≈øweet and lovely Names, I mu≈øt alter my Style according to the Matter and Occa≈øion, or el≈øe all will be out of Tune, and no more Harmony than Harp and Harrow. Bi≈øhop Jewel, and other Reformers, they wrote ≈ømartly
again≈øt the Papi≈øts, and most exqui≈øitely di≈øplayed their Errors; and yet they prote≈øted they were in Charity, and de≈øired nothing more than that they would have hearkened to them, and for≈øaken their Errors. And I do ≈øay, nothing would plea≈øe me better, than to ≈øee this People Condemn what is Erroneous amongst them, and per≈øevere in the Truth, and the Knowledge of our Lord Je≈øus Christ, True God, and Perfect Man in One Per≈øon.

Object. But if any Object in favour of them, That though they do not Preach Chri≈øt without (unle≈øs ≈øince G. K. came over) as he is in Heaven above, nor believe him to be di≈øtinct from his Saints; nor Pray in the Name of Je≈øus to God the Father, thereby owning him in his Mediator-≈øhip; nor make Confe≈ø≈øion of Sin to God in Prayer, nor beg Pardon for the ≈øame: But look at Chri≈øt within, the Light within, his Crucifixion within, his Interce≈ø≈øion within; nor a Bible to be ≈øeen in their Meetings, for they are above ≈øuch Carnal things. Yet they have among them many good Exhortations, and they own Chri≈øt to be the Word of God, the Power of God, the Wi≈ødom of God; will not this do? Suppo≈øing they mean all to be within, yea, Heaven and Hell, all within, &c.

In≈øomuch that if the Quakers do not come to this Re≈øult, to own the ≈øame Je≈øus, that was born of the Virgin, ≈ømote with Palms of their Hands, Crucified, Dead, Buried, Ro≈øe again, and in the ≈øight of the Galileans a≈øcended into Heaven, and publickly Condemn their Books, which Teach the contrary, they cannot de≈øerve the Name Chri≈øtian, &c.

I am not un≈øen≈øible what little Arts they have u≈øed to bla≈øt my Reputation, that thereby they may ob≈øtruct the Service of my Books, but their Expectation hath failed them. Then they Indicted me in London for Printing without Licen≈øe, yet they do the ≈øame. But they ≈øay, I put up a Mock-Pillory; I grant I did, and that to ≈øhew what they actually de≈øerved upon their own Propo≈øals to Authority. Did not they erect the Form and Figure of a Child's Penny horning Battle-door for the Bi≈øhops, Clergy, and Gentry to Learn the Engli≈øh of Tu and Vos? Signed by G. Fox, a Shoe-maker, &c. How did they run up and down to great Per≈øons, both on Foot, and by Coach, and all to Suppre≈øs me? And had they had a Jury of Quakers, I had been Ca≈øt, but the Jury brought in the Bill Ignoramus, &c. to the great Satisfaction of the Honourable Court. Thus did they begin here, as the Quakers did in Pen≈øilyania, who Per≈øecuted G. Keith and his Friends for their Chri≈øtian
Te≈øtimony, notwith≈øtanding their Pretences that the Lord hath laid it upon them not to go to Law, nor avenge them≈øelves, and that the di≈øpo≈øition of their Nature is not to ≈øeck Revenge; for (≈øay they) ≈øuch as do are in the Fall, &c. Yet the≈øe Pretences are like the re≈øt of their Sophi≈øtry, for had they Power, few ≈øhould exceed them in Per≈øecution and Cruelty. For methinks I hear them ≈øay, Come, let us ≈øay, He is a Pe≈øtilent Fellow, a mover of Sedition, we mu≈øt u≈øe all the Arts we have to ≈øtop him; for he ≈øeems to follow the ≈øteps of M. Luther, that Apo≈øtate Adver≈øary of our dear Elder Si≈øter. And if he goes on, he will ≈øo unvail us, that all People will know us and our Intrigues: Come, let us be≈øpatter him, and cover him with ≈øome frightful Bea≈øt's Skin, and then ≈øet our little Curs to bait and worry him, to abu≈øe and be≈øpatter him in City and Country, &c. body.p: AS there is Joy in Heaven over a Sinner converted to God as to his Morals, ≈øo when the Erroneous turn to the true God, as to his Intellectuals, Truth and Goodne≈øs being his Infinite Attributes, the ≈øhadow of them (for in the Creature they are no better) are equally plea≈øing to their Author. Hence I may ≈øhew my Joy, in that my Neighbour Bugg is returned from his Errors, (not as to his Life, for he was ≈øober ever ≈øince I knew him) but as to his Judgment; as a ≈øign of which he has laboured to bring over his ≈øeduced Brethren, which, would they read his Books, might be done; but I fear mo≈øt of them are of the mind of one of them that told me, Thou mai≈øt out-argue me, but ≈øhalt not per≈øwade me. However I do own the Sub≈øtance of this Book i. e. The fir≈øt Impre≈ø≈øion., as a Defence of tho≈øe Eternal Truths by which I hope for Salvation, and which are a Comfort to me in my Pilgrimage. div.p: Come, G. W. I have found room to recite my Teacher, verbatim, but I want both time and room to draw the exact Picture of G. W. who for audacious In≈øolency, Pride, and Self-conceit; for Scorn, Contempt, and Envy; for Defaming, Glo≈ø≈øing, Perverting, and Subtilty; for denying what you know to be true, and affirming what you know to be fal≈øe: I ≈øay, to ≈øet forth your exact Picture in the≈øe and other the like Crafty Jugglings and Legerdemain, to trace your Books, to rip you up, and make a perfect Di≈øcovery of your two-fac'd Pretences and Practices, it would require a Volume. body.p: SIR, I heartily Congratulate your return to our Church, which doubtle≈øs is the mo≈øt Eminent for Doctrine, Wor≈øhip, and Di≈øcipline amongst all the Reformed Churches in the World; I cannot but highly commend your Pious Endeavours for this End, of which I have received an Account from Mr. Gearing A London Mini≈øter.: I ≈øhall much rejoyce in your Succe≈øs herein‚ÄîIn order to undeceive them poor ≈øeduced People, having therein di≈øplay'd many of the Intrigues of their Leaders.

Papi≈øts) are grown ≈øo complai≈øant, as none ≈øeem more exa≈øperated at Per≈øecution than them≈øelves (WHILST THE VERY FATHERS OF IT) decrying the fiercene≈øs of ≈øome Countries (WHOSE INCENDIARIES THEY WERE, AND STILL ARE) and imputing the Blood of poor Prote≈øtants to ≈øome unwarrantable Civil ≈øoore, (THEREBY ABUSING THE MAGISTRATE WITH THE EXECUTION OF THEIR OWN CONSPIRACIES) Nay, for all their venerable e≈øteem of the Popes Infallibility, they have not ≈øtuck to cen≈øure his roaring Bulls, (THOUGH PROCURED BY THEIR OWN MEANS) and all that might expre≈øs their new tenderne≈øs, that many unacquainted with their practices, are ready to believe them what they ≈øay them≈øelves to be, who≈øe Moral is, to have two ≈øtrings to their Bow, to be ambo dexter, and furni≈øht with meanings to ≈øute the compa≈øs of all occa≈øions. And whoever ob≈øerves the≈øe Quakers turnings and windings in all their Juglings and Ledjerdemain, will find they tread the ≈øame Path, tho' in another manner; for who will, or can pretend more plainly to own the Precepts and Doctrine of the Bible to be holy and ble≈ø≈øed; and yet in other Books ≈øay 'tis du≈øt and death, the Serpents Meat, and that to preach out of them is Conjuration, and that the Mini≈øter of the Letter is the Mini≈øter of Death, and that 'tis dangerous to read the Scriptures, and ≈øo in mo≈øt things they look two ways, JANUS like, in≈øomuch that for W. Penn's four In≈øtances of the Papi≈øts Hypocri≈øie, I could ea≈øily give you forty of the≈øe Quakers two-fac'd Practices, looking one way and rowing another: in ≈øhort, ≈øee W. P.'s. Penn) if we would not receive a Thief until he has repented, let the Papi≈øts fir≈øt Recant his volumous Errours, &c. And ≈øo ≈øay I, let the Quakers fir≈øt condemn their Errours, and the≈øe their Books, which contain them, and manife≈øt their ≈øincerity touching the Precepts

As to what G. W. offers in his Charitable E≈ø≈øay, &c. p. 2, 3. in your Vindication about you Creed cited by me in New Rome, &c. rather confirms what I ≈øay, then otherwi≈øe, as will more fully appear by comparing the ≈øame with what followeth in this Di≈øcour≈øe; as well as ≈øhew G. W. as in his Just Inquiry, &c. p. 14. ≈øays as he doth, viz. THE LIBELLER HAS SHAMEFULLY MISREPRESENTED US: as is u≈øual with you and all Hereticks to complain of being wronged and mi≈ørepre≈øented, &c. As for in≈øtance:

1. Tell the Papi≈øts of wor≈øhipping Images, praying to Saints, the Sacrifice of the Ma≈øs, that they believe their own Traditions (or Epi≈øtles) as firmly as they do the Bible, that they believe Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, Indulgencies, &c. as drawn up by Pius the Fourth, according to the Decrees and Canons of the Council of Trent, and the CONSEQUENCES of the≈øe their erronious Principles, and they will tell you they are MISREPRESENTED.

3. Tell the Ne≈øtorians, that they made two Per≈øons in Chri≈øt, and they will tell you they are MISREPRESENTED; for all they de≈øigned was to avoid the Bla≈øphemy, in calling the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin the Mother of God.

3. Tell the Eutychians their Errour in ≈øaying there was but one Nature in Chri≈øt, and they will tell you they are MISREPRESENTED; for (≈øay they) we do not mean thereby to de≈øtroy the Properties of the Humane Nature, but only to a≈ø≈øert that its Sub≈øtance was ≈øwallowed up by the Divine.

And therefore in all Complaints of this Nature, it is nece≈ø≈øary to come to particulars, and to examin with care and diligence the matter complained of, and then to give Judgment in the Ca≈øe; and therefore I cannot be thought to mi≈ørepre≈øent you, nor wrong you, if I charge you with Particulars, and tho≈øe Particulars too taken and fairly quoted, not out of ≈øuch Books as have been wrote again≈øt you, (which yet might be true enough) but out of your own approved Books wrote by your mo≈øt Authentick Writers ≈øolemnly profe≈ø≈øing to all the World I would not wrong you, nor mi≈ørepre≈øent you, nor, to my knowledge, have I done it; if you think I have, I have given you a fair opportunity to make it appear, if you will meet me on the Condition afore≈øaid; and if you can ≈øhew me wherein I have, I further ingage to do you Ju≈øtice by a Publick Reparation: And by the≈øe Mea≈øures I have proceeded from fir≈øt to la≈øt, and by the help of GOD I am re≈øolved ≈øo to continue as long as I have to do with you. div.head: NEW ROME ARRAIGNED, And out of her own Mouth CONDEMNED.
The PREFACE.
div.p:
EDw. Burrough long ≈øince put forth a Challenge in the Name of the Quakers, that they would gladly be manife≈øt to all the World; and in order to it, and to clear them≈øelves from ≈øome Imputations ca≈øt upon them, they propo≈øed to meet and Di≈øpute with any, whether Prie≈øts or People, of any Per≈øwa≈øion, yea, or any one of them, at any Place, and at any Time, and for what Number they plea≈øed, as by me recited in my la≈øt New Rome unmasked, &c. p. 2. Upon which I went to their Meeting in Mildenhall, Nov. 22. 1691. and there accepted of their Challenge, and told them, I had a Charge to exhibit again≈øt them, if they would ingage to vindicate them≈øelves and their Principles. So then I read the Charge to them, con≈øi≈øting of ten or twelve Errours, as in New Rome, &c. p. 3, 4, 5. and left a Copy of the ≈øaid Charge with them,
and told them, That if they did not an≈øwer me according to their Propo≈øition, that I ≈øhould expo≈øe them (which I was loath to do for the ≈øake of ≈øome amongst them). But no an≈øwer could I get: After which I printed, &c. and when my Book came out, I went again to their Publick Meeting, and renewed my Charge on the 20th of Nov. 1692. and offered then to prove it again≈øt them, where was pre≈øent Sam. Cater and John Cade, two of their Preachers: But ≈øtill they refu≈øed to debate the matter with me, or to argue the Point fully. I told them I did not come to di≈øturb them; but if they would ≈øet a time, either S. C. and my ≈øelf ≈øingly, or let him take two, four, ≈øix, or ten, and I would take the like number, and we would appoint a convenient time and place. This they refu≈øed, and to this day have declined any ≈øuch method, though propo≈øed by them in print; and now at la≈øt I have received a ≈øingle ≈øheet, ≈øtiled, A Charitable E≈ø≈øay, &c. which neither they, nor I can call an An≈øwer; only in p. 8. Twelve of the Duakers ≈øums up in gro≈øs four Particulars by way of Certificate, and at the end thus concludes; viz. Whereupon we do in the holy fear of Almighty God, and in behalf of the ≈øaid People, declare and te≈øtifie, That all the≈øe and all other his (F. Bs.) Accu≈øations of the ≈øame kind, or depending thereupon, are utterly fal≈øe, wicked, and malicious, and never ≈øo believed, ≈øo ≈øaid, nor ≈øo affirmed by us as charged again≈øt us, but contrary to our Per≈øwa≈øion, Principle, and Profe≈ø≈øion, &c.

Behold the An≈øwer of the≈øe Twelve Elders, is contained in le≈øs than half a Page; and how far their plain Say-≈øo will prevail again≈øt plain Matter of Fact, unle≈øs with their own infatuated Di≈øciples, let the wi≈øe in heart judge? And in an≈øwer to this ≈øaid Certificate, I do thus ≈øay, That to my knowledge, I have not ≈øet down one Line nor Word as theirs, that is not theirs, nor yet rai≈øed one Argument upon theirs, but may naturally be drawn from the Premi≈øes; and if they think I have, I with the like number will upon rea≈øonable notice meet them at any place within twenty Miles or more of my dwelling, and produce both Book and Page, and if they can ≈øhew me wherein I have wronged them, I will make them publick Satisfaction, on condition that if what I have wrote as their Principles, be by me ≈øo proved, that then they will condemn what is apparently Erronious; and as this will be a fair opportunity for them (if they think them≈øelves wronged, as they pretend) to clear them≈øelves from my Accu≈øations as they call them; ≈øo will they have an opportunity to manife≈øt Francis Bugg to be both wicked and malicious; yea, and I will al≈øo ≈øub≈øcribe to this their Sentance, if I do not clear my ≈øelf, and fully prove my Charge again≈øt them. But, as a ≈øign that they do not think nor believe them≈øelves ≈øo wronged, as they pretend, although I do not pretend to their Art of Prophe≈øying, yet I do, and dare pa≈øs my word that they will never meet me, and ≈øub≈øcribe the Condition afore≈øaid.
And I have no other rea≈øon thus to believe, but that I know fir≈øt, 'tis their way to make a large Prote≈øtation of their avowed Innocency, when Guilty; and that ≈øecondly, I know they cannot but be con≈øcious of great guilt in denying and out-facing ≈øuch manife≈øt Truths, as in that half Page they have done. As to G. Whitehead in the Introduction, I have taken ≈øome little notice of him, and what he hath ≈øaid, which is but little, being not a ≈øheet; neither hath he taken notice of the twentieth part of my Book; ≈øo that it ≈øtill ≈øtands unan≈øwered and un≈øhaken by their peny Rattle which they have put forth to plea≈øe their Di≈øciples; for ≈øomething they mu≈øt ≈øay, or the People will cry, Where is the An≈øwer to F. list.head: THE CHARGE.
list.item: F. B's. Charge again≈øt the Quakers. 1. The Quakers denies him who was born of the Virgin Mary, who ≈øuffered death upon the Cro≈øs at Jeru≈øalem, who ro≈øe again the third day, and a≈øcended into Heaven in the ≈øight of the Galileans, to be Chri≈øt the Saviour of the World.
2. They deny the Scriptures, by ≈øpeaking contemptuou≈øly of them, and overvaluing their own Books.

3. That their Teachers are Deceivers of the People, Favourers of Bla≈øphemy, Excu≈øers of Idolatry, and of a different Faith from the Apo≈øtles, Primitive Chri≈øtians and ble≈ø≈øed Martyrs, and that their Doctrine tends to overthrow the Chri≈øtian Faith.

div.p:
This is the Charge which I publickly exhibited, this is the Charge I offered to prove again≈øt them, which as it is heavy, ≈øo it ≈øtood them upon to have defended them≈øelves, if they had been able ≈øo to do, ≈øince they had two of their Preachers pre≈øent, be≈øides hundreds of People to bear witne≈øs what pa≈ø≈øed: Nay, though con≈øcious to them≈øelves of being guilty (as that I take to be the very rea≈øon of evading a Di≈øpute) yet notwith≈øtanding it had been for their intere≈øt, if they had been humble, and for Truth and Righteou≈øne≈øs, as they pretend; who upon Conviction of their Errours, ought to have made open Confe≈ø≈øion thereof to GOD's glory, as was the practice of the ancient Martyrs upon a ≈øight of the Papi≈øts Super≈øtitions, in which they had walked. However, ≈øince they would not accept of the ≈øaid Challenge; nor yet meet me according to my frequent Propo≈øals, nor an≈øwer my Book, but come only out with a ≈øingle ≈øheet, and tell their People, this is an An≈øwer to F. B's. Book, &c. when alas!
it doth not take notice of the twentieth part thereof: I ≈øhall now proceed to prove upon them what I have Charged them with, and that out of their own approved Books, and Arguments deduceable from them. But let it be noted, that their ERROURS and CONSEQUENCES under di≈øtinct Heads numerically placed, are taken verbatim out of their own Books, which is plain Matter of Fact, quoting both Book and Page; but the Remarks and Arguments I draw from them are my own ≈øence, which how far they agree to Rea≈øon and Prote≈øtant Chri≈øtian Principles, I leave others to judge: And in order thereunto, I fir≈øt divide my Charge into three parts as followeth, viz.

div.head: THE FIRST CHARGE.
div.p: F. B's. fir≈øt Charge.1. THAT THE Quakers DENY HIM THAT WAS BORN OF THE VIRGIN MARY, WHO SUFFERED DEATH UPON THE CROSS AT JERUSALEM, WHO ROSE AGAIN THE THIRD DAY, AND ASCENDED INTO HEAVEN, IN THE SIGHT OF THE GALILEANS, TO BE CHRIST THE SAVIOUR OF THE WORLD.

div.head: THE Quakers FIRST ERROUR.
div.p: The Quakers fir≈øt Errour. A Que≈øtion to the Profe≈ø≈øors, &c. p. 33. Now the Scriptures do expre≈øly di≈øtingui≈øh between CHRIST and the GARMENT which he wore, between HIM that came, and the BODY in which he CAME; between the Sub≈øtance which was vailed, and the Vail which vailed it, Lo I come, a Body ha≈øt thou prepared me; there is plainly HE, and the Body in which HE came; there was the outward VESSEL, and the inward LIFE. This we certainly know, and can never call the bodily Garment Chri≈øt, &c.

By which 'tis plain that they deny HIM that was born of the Virgin to be CHRIST; for though they ≈øeem to own ≈øomething which appeared in the Body, as by the ≈øequel of the matter you will perceive, yet 'tis plain, and ≈øelf-evident, that they call HIM that was born of the Virgin, that ≈øuffered Death on the Cro≈øs, who was ≈ømote with the Palms of their Hands, ≈øpit upon, buffetted, and run through with a Spear, died, was buried, ro≈øe again the third day, &c. but a Garment, a Vail, a Figure, &c. For ≈øay the Quakers, There was plainly HE, and the Body in which HE came; there was plainly the outward Garment and the inward Life, &c. And
this we declare to all Mankind we can never call this Body; this Garment that was thus ≈øubject to be ≈ømote, to be buffetted, to be peri≈øhed, to be crucified, &c. CHRIST. But if that will ≈øatisfie you, we will call ≈øomething that was in that Body, which was never born of a Woman, never was mortal, never ≈ømote, never crucified, nor by wicked hands ≈ølain, and hanged on a Tree; this if it will ≈øatisfie you, we will call CHRIST, being the ≈øame which we ≈øay is in us: This, and no other, do, or ever did we own to be CHRIST the Saviour of the World.

Now that this is a Fundamental Errour, and tends to overthrow the Chri≈øtian Faith, I ≈øhall prove by the Te≈øtimony of the glorious Angels, holy Apo≈øtles, yea GOD him≈øelf, recorded in Sacred Writ. And fir≈øt read Luke 2. 11. For unto you is BORN this day, in the City of David, a Saviour, CHRIST the LORD. And Acts 5. 30, 31. The GOD of our Fathers rai≈øed up Je≈øus, whom ye SLEW and HANGED on a Tree: HIM hath GOD exalted with His right Hand to be a Prince and a SAVIOUR. Again, Acts 2. 36. Therefore let all the Hou≈øe of I≈ørael know ASSUREDLY, that GOD hath made THAT SAME JESUS, whom ye have crucified, both LORD and CHRIST. Mark, the SAME JESUS which was thus de≈øpitefully u≈øed, that was thus crucified between two Thieves, that was put to this ignominious Death, viz. hanged on a Tree: The VERY SAME JESUS the Apo≈øtle tells you, and a≈ø≈øures all the Hou≈øe of I≈ørael, that GOD exalted to be a Prince and a Saviour, to be both LORD and CHRIST. Again, read St. Mark 9. 7. and Matth. 17. 5. And there was a cloud that over-≈øhadowed them, and a voice came out of the cloud, ≈øaying, This is MY beloved SON, hear ye HIM. Again, read Acts 1. 10, 11. And whil≈øt they looked ≈øteadfa≈øtly toward Heaven, as HE went UP, behold two men ≈øtood by them in white Apparel, which al≈øo ≈øaid, Ye men of Galilee, why ≈øtand ye gazing UP into Heaven? THIS SAME JESUS which is taken up FROM Then not in them in the Quakers ≈øence; no, no otherwi≈øe then by Faith, nor no otherwi≈øe to this day; for Chri≈øt ≈øaid at His la≈øt Supper, ME ye have not always; its expedient that I go away, but when I am gone I will ≈øend the Comforter.
you into Heaven, ≈øhall ≈øo come in LIKE MANNER as YE have ≈øeen him go into Heaven. And Acts 10. 39, 40, 41. the ≈øame is again verified of the SAME JESUS. And thereupon I do affirm and te≈øtifie, and charge it upon them, in the pre≈øence of GOD, Angels and Men, that they di≈øown and deny Je≈øus Christ, whom GOD hath ordained to be Salvation to the ends of the Earth, and a propitiotary Sacrifice for the Sins of the whole World, to be CHRIST: And that there is not another Name given whereby men ≈øhall be ≈øaved, than this SAME JESUS; who was ≈øo named of the Angel before he was born of the Virgin, Matth. 1. 21. Luke 2. 21, 27. who was crucified, hanged on a Tree, ro≈øe the third day, and a≈øcended vi≈øibly up to Heaven, and there ≈øits at the right hand of GOD, making interce≈ø≈øion
for us ≈øinners, who believe and hope for Salvation through his Merits, Death, and bitter Pa≈ø≈øion, and the imputation of his Righteou≈øne≈øs, who was foretold by the Prophets, and in due time was manife≈øt. And this is HE that I≈ørael by Faith drank of, that the Apo≈øtles te≈øtified of, who≈øe hands handled, and eyes ≈øaw; and we by Faith do now behold, and by HIS Spirit, the Comforter, whom HE promi≈øed to ≈øend, are inabled to believe. And this I further te≈øtifie, That from Adam to the days of the Apo≈øtles, there never was a Man ≈øaved but by Faith in this Me≈ø≈øiah, or Son of GOD, nor ≈øince to this day, nor will be to the end of the World, but by this SAME JESUS who was thus born, who ≈øuffered death, who thus ro≈øe again and vi≈øibly a≈øcended; for ≈øo ≈øay the Scriptures: There is not another Name given under Heaven by which men ≈øhall be ≈øaved, but by the Name of JESUS: even as St. Peter often, and very emphatically illu≈øtrates, ≈øaying, This SAME JESUS. And this Je≈øus the Quakers ≈øay they cannot call CHRIST; for though I grant this was H. Penington's great Errour, yet as G. W. ≈øays, he was a wi≈øe Man and a Scholar; nay, let me add, A Man I believe that was more ≈øimply hone≈øt than hundreds of their Teachers; [And how far GOD's mercy may extend to him and other devout Heathens, I will not determine] yet Errour is Errour ≈øtill, and the Fundamental Truths of the Go≈øpel ought to be te≈øtified to by all true Chri≈øtians, according to the holy Scriptures.

div.head: THE Quakers SECOND ERROUR.
div.p:
The Quakers ≈øecond Errour. A Que≈øt. &c. p. 20. To whom do the Names and Titles of JESUS and CHRIST chiefly and in the fir≈øt place belong? Do they belong to the Body which was took by HIM; or to him [too hims by the way] who took the Body? The Body hath its Names and Properties. Now the Query is, which was the appointed Saviour of the Father? which was the Anointed of the Father
viz. The Light in them, or Chri≈øt that ≈øuffered on the Cro≈øs. This is the Que≈øtion, ob≈øerve his An≈øwer. chiefly and in the first place? whether the Body prepared, or He [i. e. the Light] for whom the Body was prepared? For that which He took upon Him was our Garment, even the Fle≈øh and Blood of our Nature, which is of an EARTHLY PERISHING NATURE.

Fir≈øt I an≈øwer, The Name JESUS and CHRIST chiefly and in the fir≈øt place belongs to HIM that was born of the Virgin, that ≈øuffered death on the Cro≈øs, that was buried in the Sepulchre, that ro≈øe again and vi≈øibly a≈øcended, as in my la≈øt Remark I have already proved, from the
joint Te≈øtimony of the glorious Angels, Matth. 1. 2. Luke 2. 10, 11. and holy Apo≈øtles, Acts 2. 36. and 5. 30, 31. and Acts 1. 10, 11. Luke 2. 21, 27. and could by many other places. And next to their Affirmation, That HIS Body was like ours, of an earthly peri≈øhing Nature, I deny: For ≈øaid St. Peter, Acts 2. 29, 30, 31. Men and Brethren, let me freely ≈øpeak to you of the Patriarch David, that he is both dead and buried, and his Sepulchre is with us unto this day: therefore being a Prophet, and knowing that GOD had ≈øworn by an Oath to him,
Acts 13. 35. that of the fruit of his Loyns according to the Fle≈øh, he would rai≈øe up CHRIST to ≈øit on his Throne; he ≈øeeing this before ≈øpake of the Re≈øurrection of CHRIST, That his Soul was not left in Hell, neither his Fle≈øh did ≈øee Corruption, P≈øal. 32. 11. and 110. 1. By which 'tis plain, that CHRIST who was born of the Virgin, who ≈øuffered death, and was buried, was not of an earthly peri≈øhing Nature: and as plain, that by their calling HIS Body a Garment, a Vail, a Figure, &c. and ≈øaying it was like ours, of an earthly peri≈øhing nature, that they deny CHRIST and di≈øown HIM; yea, further, that the very Name of JESUS and CHRIST do not properly belong to HIM, as is implied by the beginning of their Que≈øtion, and confirmed by their Re≈øolving their Que≈øtion, in ≈øaying, For that which he took upon him [meaning his Body] was our Garment, even the Fle≈øh and Blood of our Nature, which is of AN EARTHLY PERISHING NATURE. For you mu≈øt note, the≈øe Que≈øtions were not propo≈øed to be an≈øwered by others, but a compleat Book put forth by way of Que≈øtion fir≈øt, and by H. Penington him≈øelf al≈øo an≈øwered, for the clearing up what they did, or did not own to be CHRIST; and the Tenor of it runs to own the Light, the Life, the Sub≈øtance, ≈øomething in the Body which was not capable of being ≈øeen otherwi≈øe than by the Eye of Faith, nor capable of wearine≈øs, of thir≈øt, of hunger, of buffetting, of ≈øcourging, of being crucified, and hanged on a Tree; this in a confu≈øed my≈øterious ≈øence they will own to be CHRIST; and this is no other than they dream is in them, and which they attribute to one another, as in the ≈øaid Con≈øequences of the≈øe their Errours I ≈øhall more evidently make appear. Nay, they ≈øay, A Que≈øt. &c. p. 22. Is not this [the Light in them] the ≈øame Chri≈øt that took upon him the Body of Fle≈øh, and offered it without the Gates of Jeru≈øalem, &c. So that con≈øequently ≈øo many Quakers, ≈øo many CHRISTS, as anon will more plainly appear.

div.head: THE Quakers THIRD ERROUR.
